docs.lead_paragraph: A new vaccine, previously thought to protect uninfected women who have infected partners, has now been found useless against herpes simplex virus-2 in a double-blinded placebo-controlled trial.

headline.seo: Herpes Vaccine Falls Short in Clinical Trial
headline.main: Herpes Vaccine Falls Short in Clinical Trial
headline.print_headline: Prevention: Herpes Vaccine Falls Short in Clinical Trial

docs.abstract: Study co-authored by Peter A Leone and published in The New England Journal of Medicine finds that latest vaccine, developed to protect uninfected women against both types of herpes simplex is useless against the HSV-2 virus, which causes genital herpes.
docs.snippet: A new vaccine, previously thought to protect uninfected women who have infected partners, has now been found useless against herpes simplex virus-2 in a double-blinded placebo-controlled trial.

docs.lead_paragraph: Marriage counseling is evolving to help couples survive personality changes and physical challenges.

headline.main: When Injuries to the Brain Tear at Hearts
headline.print_headline: When Injuries To the Brain Tear at Hearts

docs.abstract: Marriage counseling is evolving to help couples survive personality changes and physical challenges following brain injuries; counselors say that the best technique is often to encourage couples to forge a new relationship based on the profound changes that brain injuries can cause.
docs.snippet: Marriage counseling is evolving to help couples survive personality changes and physical challenges.

docs.lead_paragraph: What would happen if patients were encouraged not only to review their medical records but to really own them? A research collaboration called OpenNotes has set out to answer this question.

headline.seo: A study encourages people to take the doctor’s notes home after exams.
headline.main: Project Puts Records in the Patients’ Hands
headline.print_headline: Project Puts Records in the Patients’ Hands

docs.abstract: Dr Tom Delbanco, principal investigator of study published in journal Annals of Internal Medicine, reports on OpenNotes, a research collaboration that looked at patient and physician attitudes and reactions to creating medical records that patients could take home, study and own; while some concerns remain, overall findings are that open medical records can help patients make good decisions concerning their health between visits.
docs.snippet: What would happen if patients were encouraged not only to review their medical records but to really own them? A research collaboration called OpenNotes has set out to answer this question.

docs.lead_paragraph: The first Haitian to get cholera at the onset of the 2010 epidemic was almost undoubtedly a 28-year-old mentally disturbed man from the town of Mirebalais, researchers reported Monday.

headline.seo: Haitian Cholera Epidemic Traced to First Known Victim
headline.main: Haiti: Cholera Epidemic’s First Victim Identified as River Bather Who Forsook Clean Water
headline.print_headline: Cholera Epidemic’s First Victim Identified As River Bather Who Forsook Clean Water

docs.abstract: Report co-authored by Louise C Ivers and published in The American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene determines with near certainty that Haiti's 2010 cholera outbreak began with a mentally disturbed man in the town of Mirebalais who was bathing and drinking from a river contaminated with raw sewage.
docs.snippet: The first Haitian to get cholera at the onset of the 2010 epidemic was almost undoubtedly a 28-year-old mentally disturbed man from the town of Mirebalais, researchers reported Monday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers suggest physical activity increases the flow of blood and oxygen to the brain and may lead to increased levels of norepinephrine and endorphins.

headline.seo: Exercise Yields Dividends in the Classroom, Studies Suggest
headline.main: Childhood: Exercise Yields Dividends in the Classroom
headline.print_headline: Childhood: Exercise Yields Dividends in the Classroom

docs.abstract: Studies led by Amika S Singh and published in journal The Archives of Pediatrics & Adolescent Medicine find that physical exercise in children improves not only cardiovascular health but also academic performance.
docs.snippet: Researchers suggest physical activity increases the flow of blood and oxygen to the brain and may lead to increased levels of norepinephrine and endorphins.

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers are looking for opportunities to identify adolescents who have problems and to provide support.

headline.seo: Seeing Social Media as Adolescent Portal More Than Pitfall
headline.main: Seeing Social Media More as Portal Than as Pitfall
headline.print_headline: Seeing Social Media More as Portal Than as Pitfall

docs.abstract: Researchers are looking for opportunities to identify adolescents who have internet-related problems without exaggerating the dangers posed by social media and other emerging technologies; some experts have begun to think of social media as another adolescent rite of passage, similar to driving, which must be treated with caution.
docs.snippet: Researchers are looking for opportunities to identify adolescents who have problems and to provide support.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two studies in The Journal of the American Medical Association provide new clues, but many questions remain.

headline.seo: Stillbirth Causes Are Tallied, but Risks Remain a Challenge
headline.main: New Clues Revealed in Studies of Stillbirth
headline.print_headline: New Clues Revealed In Studies Of Stillbirth

docs.abstract: Two studies published in The Journal of the American Medical Association identify the most common causes of stillbirth, which occurs at a higher rate in the United States than in many other developed countries; studies find that known risk factors explain only a minority of stillbirth cases and conclude that more research is needed, particularly concerning disparities among races and ethnicities.
docs.snippet: Two studies in The Journal of the American Medical Association provide new clues, but many questions remain.

keywords.value: Journal of the American Medical Assn
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: A new book called “30 Lessons for Living” draws from interviews with more than 1,000 older Americans from different economic, educational and occupational strata.

headline.seo: Elderly ‘Experts’ Share Life Advice in Cornell Project
headline.main: Advice From Life’s Graying Edge on Finishing With No Regrets
headline.print_headline: Advice From Life’s Graying Edge on Finishing With No Regrets

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column reviews advice drawn from interviews with more than 1,000 older Americans and collected in book 30 Lessons for Living by Karl Pillemer.
docs.snippet: A new book called “30 Lessons for Living” draws from interviews with more than 1,000 older Americans from different economic, educational and occupational strata.

docs.lead_paragraph: Friends or relatives in the last third of their lives may have advice that may improve your own chances of living successfully.

headline.seo: 10 Things to Ask When Seeking Life Lessons
headline.main: Questions for Your Own Circle of Experts
headline.print_headline: Questions for Your Own Circle of Experts

docs.abstract: Examples of questions that are effective in drawing valuable advice from elders, in light of book 30 Lessons for Living by Karl Pillemer.
docs.snippet: Friends or relatives in the last third of their lives may have advice that may improve your own chances of living successfully.

headline.main: Worrying Less About Teens, Texting and Social Media

docs.abstract: Much of the early research — and many of the early pronouncements — on social media seemed calculated to make parents terrified of an emerging technology that many of them did not understand as well as their children did.
docs.snippet: Much of the early research — and many of the early pronouncements — on social media seemed calculated to make parents terrified of an emerging technology that many of them did not understand as well as their children did.
